instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P3V42_G3H: What is P3V42_G3H? P3V42_G3H is a typo of PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Missing <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi

Originally this macbook came in without a light on the charger, the customer did not know of any water damage but some other company told them there was corrosion (and they made and showed pictures I have in my possession as well), they 'Chemically cleaned" it (read: Drop it in the ultrasonic and call it a fix) and it worked for a good 3 months until it just crashed and never came back on again.

Just after opening I saw a very ugly looking <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> which measured >10MOhm resistance, instead of the 1MOhm it should've. The Coil didn't look very well either, and I replaced both for good measure. Macbook worked again and kept working for a couple of days before it had the same issue again.

The board looks somewhat clean for a board this old, no signs of bad corrosion and all components are looking okay.

I found that <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> was defective, as there was power going in but nothing coming out even though there is no short on the line and replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
It still had the same issues, but I thought that maybe I broke it with too much heat, bad soldering or just bad chip. So I tried it again with a new chip while being extra careful of its environment, however the issue stayed.

VIN(7)/EN(4) = 18.4V
VCC(8)/FB(2) = 3.74V
SW(6) = 0V
BYP(9) = 0V (Obviously)

<RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> = 998kOhm
No short to ground on <SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_SW</SIGNAL>
No short to ground on <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

Any idea?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Missing <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Missing <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Aha

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> is ~3.7-4.2V (Pin 1)

This should be directly tied to <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> if I'm not mistaken?
May I get away with soldering a wire from <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> from underneath the board to Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>? Or should I look somewhere else for what might be pulling it down?

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 22186"]Bad traces to <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>.....[/QUOTE]

Just figured it out as well, read text above

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Missing <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have run a long wire a few times. I don't think there is a closer point to take it from.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Missing <SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Alright, I soldered a wire from the bottom to <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR> and it works again

Thanks duke!
